author: m.kalinin
content: Following up our JSON-RPC vs REST API discussion. Securing JSON-RPC endpoint is as easy as securing REST endpoint? What kind of authentication mechanism do we want to support? I feel like JSON-RPC implementations might have lack of supporting some authentication mechanisms that regular web servers that would serve RESTful API might support out of the box. Is this worth considering at all?

author: m.kalinin
content: Also, we decided to wrap up Rayonism and now running the last devnet which is called Nocturne. After that client teams will be busy with Altair and London, in the mean time researchers will keep working on the spec side, open questions and prototypes like withdrawals, transition process, sharding. Then we get back together and spawn a larger merge testnet, potentially with state sync, new consensus api implementation and focus our efforts on merge. This is the rough plan that has been discussed recently and that makes sense to me.

author: .vbuterin
content: What is the plan on implementing the transition process?

author: .vbuterin
content: That seems to me like the main critical thing that is not yet implemented, no?

author: m.kalinin
content: The plan is to spec it out and implement in Teku first as I will be working on it. Then try it out in a small devnet which can be easily launched with usage of scripts that we already have. This is gonna be my priority after Rayonism. What I'd like to do first is to understand how to better extrapolate total difficulty with usage of the block corresponding to `eth1_data.block_hash`, what would happen if we get difficulty increase or a drop off after this block, how would it affect our extrapolation.

author: m.kalinin
content: It's definitely critical in terms of the merge. We have been focused on the post-merge fork first to get implemented the stage which we want to eventually come to. And we seem succeeded on it, we have 3 execution engines and 4 consensus clients so far which is more than was expected. IMHO, prototyping transition process doesn't require them all to be involved from the beginning.
